'''Jolie Holland''' (born September 11, 1975)<ref name="AMG">{{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/jolie-holland-mn0000820652|title=Jolie Holland Songs, Albums, Reviews, Bio & More|website=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref> is an American singer and performer who combines elements of [[Folk music|folk]], [[Traditional music|traditional]], [[experimental music|experimental]], and rock.<ref name=QUIET>{{cite web|url=http://quietcolor.com/qc/?p=1203 |title=Qc Interview: Jolie Holland |website=Quietcolor.com |date=October 6, 2008 |access-date=2014-05-20}}</ref>

==Career==
[[File:Jolie Holland performing at the Kings Arms in Auckland.jpg|thumb|180px|right|Holland at the keyboards]]  
Growing up in her birth place of [[Houston]], Texas,<ref name="AMG"/> Holland left in 1994, moving to [[Austin, Texas|Austin]], [[New Orleans]], and [[San Francisco]] before ending up in [[Vancouver]], Canada, where she was one of the founding members of [[The Be Good Tanyas]]. Holland left the band before the release of their debut album, ''[[Blue Horse (album)|Blue Horse]]'', on which she appears prominently.<ref>{{cite web|author=Erik Hage |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/the-be-good-tanyas-mn0000031969/biography |title=The Be Good Tanyas | Biography |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=2014-05-20}}</ref> She returned to San Francisco, where she recorded her first album, 2002's ''[[Catalpa (album)|Catalpa]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/Jolie-Holland-Catalpa/release/3818458|title=Jolie Holland – Catalpa (2003, CD)|website=Discogs.com}}</ref> Originally self-released, the album was later picked up and re-released by [[ANTI-]]. In 2004 she released her first album for ANTI-, 2004's ''[[Escondida (album)|Escondida]]''. ANTI- labelmates [[Tom Waits]] and [[Sage Francis]] are both outspoken fans of Holland's: Waits nominated her for the [[Shortlist Prize|Shortlist music prize]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/jolie-holland-mn0000820652 |title=Jolie Holland | Music Biography, Credits and Discography |website=AllMusic |date=May 17, 1976 |access-date=2014-05-20}}</ref> while Francis has said that ''Escondida'' was his most listened to album of 2005.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/music/chi-0701190157jan19,1,3256114.story?coll=chi-ent_music-hed |title=Topic Galleries |website=Chicagotribune.com |access-date=2014-05-20}}</ref>

As well as releasing another four solo albums for ANTI- and touring globally, Holland has performed a number of collaborations with other artists, including with fan Sage Francis (on his album ''[[Human the Death Dance]])'' and [[Booker T. Jones|Booker T.]] (with whom she recorded "[[What A Wonderful World]]" in 2007). In 2016, she reunited with Be Good Tanyas bandmate Samantha Parton and they began touring as a duo,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thefestival.bc.ca/artists/jolie-holland-and-samantha-parton/|publisher=2016 Vancouver Folk Music Festival|title=Jolie Holland and Samantha Parton (California/British Columbia)|access-date=25 November 2016}}</ref> releasing the jointly-credited album ''Wildflower Blues'', on Cinquefoil Records, in 2017 and embarking on a joint tour through 2018.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://jolieandsamantha.com/ |title = Jolie Holland and Samantha Parton|website=Jolieandsamantha.com}}</ref>

== Discography ==
=== Studio albums ===
* ''[[Catalpa (album)|Catalpa]]'' (2003)
* ''[[Escondida (album)|Escondida]]'' (2004)
* ''[[Springtime Can Kill You]]'' (2006)
* ''[[The Living and the Dead (Jolie Holland album)|The Living and the Dead]]'' (2008)
* ''Pint of Blood'' (2011)
* ''[[Wine Dark Sea (Jolie Holland album)|Wine Dark Sea]]'' (2014)
* ''Wildflower Blues'' with Samantha Parton (2017)
* ''Haunted Mountain'' (2023)

=== Live albums ===
* ''[[Jolie Holland and The Quiet Orkestra]]'' (2002)

=== Contributions ===
* Multiple vocal, instrumental, and writing contributions on the [[Be Good Tanyas]]' debut album, [[Blue Horse (album)|''Blue Horse'']], released in 2000 (after Holland's departure from the band).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/The-Be-Good-Tanyas-Blue-Horse/release/1896977|title=The Be Good Tanyas – Blue Horse (2000, CD)|website=Discogs.com}}</ref>
* Multiple collaborations with [[David Dondero]], including backing vocals on the song "Analysis of a 1970's Divorce" on Dondero's 2001 album ''Shooting at the Sun With a Water Gun''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/shooting-at-the-sun-with-a-water-gun-mw0000592422/credits |title=Shooting at the Sun With a Water Gun – David Dondero | Credits |website=AllMusic |date=November 13, 2001 |access-date=2014-05-20}}</ref>
* Lead vocals on ''The Grey Funnel Line'' on [[Hal Willner]]'s ''[[Rogue's Gallery: Pirate Ballads, Sea Songs, and Chanteys]]'' (2006, [[ANTI-]])<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/rogues-gallery-pirate-ballads-sea-songs-chanteys-mw0000403221/credits |title=Music Search, Recommendations, Videos and Reviews |website=AllMusic |access-date=2014-05-20}}</ref>
* Backing vocals for [[Bad Religion]] frontman Greg Graffin's studio solo album ''[[Cold as the Clay]]''<ref>{{cite web|author=Corey Apar |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/cold-as-the-clay-mw0000410750 |title=Cold as the Clay – Greg Graffin | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |website=AllMusic |date=July 11, 2006 |access-date=2014-05-20}}</ref>
* Violin on The Speakers' album ''Yeats Is Greats''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cdbaby.com/cd/speakers4 |title=The Speakers | Yeats Is Greats: The Speakers Sing the Poems of William Butler Yeats (and more) | CD Baby Music Store |website=Cdbaby.com |access-date=2014-05-20}}</ref>
* Backing vocals on [[Chuck Ragan]]'s album ''[[Feast or Famine (Chuck Ragan album)|Feast or Famine]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/feast-or-famine-mw0000747961/credits |title=Feast or Famine – Chuck Ragan | Credits |website=AllMusic |date=August 7, 2007 |access-date=2014-05-20}}</ref>
* Lyrics and performance of ''Flood of Dreams'' in the film ''[[King of California]]''<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0388182/soundtrack|title=Flood of Dreams soundtracks|website=IMDb.com | access-date=2014-05-13}}</ref>
* Backing vocals on "Cinders of the Sun" and "Heart of Misery"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.redorbit.com/news/entertainment/1420548/stepping_out_of_daddys_dark_shadow/ |title=Stepping Out of Daddy's Dark Shadow – Entertainment News |website=Redorbit.com |date=June 6, 2008 |access-date=2014-05-20}}</ref> for [[Steve Abel]] and the Chrysalids' album ''Flax Happyon''
* Backing vocals on [[David Gray (British musician)|David Gray's]] "Kathleen"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/song/kathleen-mt0044484409 |title=Kathleen – David Gray,Jolie Holland | Listen, Appearances, Song Review |website=AllMusic |date=September 14, 2009 |access-date=2014-05-20}}</ref>
* Contributed to two tracks on Sage Francis' ''[[Human the Death Dance]]'' and is featured in the video for "Got Up This Morning"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/human-the-death-dance-mw0000570940/credits |title=Human the Death Dance – Sage Francis | Credits |website=AllMusic |date=May 8, 2007 |access-date=2014-05-20}}</ref><ref name=Epitaph-GotUpThisMorning-MakingOf-2007>{{cite news|title=Sage Francis - Making of "Got Up This Morning"|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hQy6XVWT148 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211222/hQy6XVWT148 |archive-date=2021-12-22 |url-status=live|work=[[Epitaph Records]]|date=23 May 2007|format=Video}}{{cbignore}}</ref>
* Backing vocals on "Songs for Love Drunk Sinners" by Jan Bell and the Cheap Dates<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cdbaby.com/cd/jbcheapdates |title=Jan Bell and the Cheap Dates | Songs for Love Drunk Sinners | CD Baby Music Store |website=Cdbaby.com |date=April 17, 2008 |access-date=2014-05-20}}</ref>
* Collaboration with [[Booker T. Jones]] on the album "What A Wonderful World"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/what-a-wonderful-world-mw0001742835 |title=What a Wonderful World – Booker T. Jones | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |website=AllMusic |access-date=2014-05-20}}</ref>
* Backing vocals on "Old/New" by Frally<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/the-light/id355843355 |title=iTunes – Music – The Light by Frally |website=Itunes.apple.com |date=March 1, 2010 |access-date=2014-05-20}}</ref>
* Backing vocals on "Alabama chicken" and "Rattlesnake charm (Dream machine)" by [[Sean Hayes (musician)|Sean Hayes]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/alabama-chicken-mw0000694189/credits |title=Alabama Chicken – Sean Hayes | Credits |website=AllMusic |access-date=2014-05-20}}</ref>
* Mixing and engineering by [[Joel Hamilton]] on the album "The Living and The Dead" <ref>{{cite web|title=Jolie Holland: The Living and The Dead|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/the-living-and-the-dead-mw0000798545/credits|website=AllMusic}}</ref> 
* Duet with [[Guy Garvey]] on "Electricity" from the 2015 album ''[[Courting the Squall]]''
* Backing vocals and violin on Eric Terino's "Innovations of Grave Perversity" LP<ref>{{Cite web |title=Innovations of Grave Perversity, by Eric Terino |url=https://ericterino.bandcamp.com/album/innovations-of-grave-perversity |access-date=2022-03-13 |website=Ericterino.bandcamp.com |language=en}}</ref> and "Body Gets Stoned" EP<ref>{{Cite web |title=Body Gets Stoned (feat. Jolie Holland) - Single, by Eric Terino |url=https://ericterino.bandcamp.com/album/body-gets-stoned-feat-jolie-holland-single |access-date=2022-03-13 |website=Ericterino.bandcamp.com|language=en}}</ref>
